results.title: L'oeil du Malin = the Third Lover
results.creator_credit: Claude Chabrol, Carlo Ponti and Georges de Beauregard
results.brief_description:
A second-rate French journalist visiting West Germany to write a series of articles meets a successful author and his French wife, who appear to be an exceptionally happy couple. He insinuates himself into their lives, becomes obsessed with their relationship and attempts to seduce the wife, thereby causing destruction. One of the most elegant of Chabrol’s early works, the films presents an intriguing situation that develops with Hitchcockian undertones, even though the warped behaviour of the journalist remains somewhat of a puzzle. However Chabrol’s Peeping Tom camera is effectively used to suggest a study in voyeurism. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide.

Credits: Producers, Georges de Beauregard, Carlo Ponti ; director, Claude Chabrol ; writer, Claude Chabrol, Marcel Matthieu ; photography, Jean Rabier ; music, Pierre Jansen.
Cast: Stephane Audran, Jacques Charrier, Walter Reyer, Daniel Boulanger, Andre Badin.

results.title: L'ironie du Sort = Irony of Chance
results.brief_description:
Set in Nantes, during the German Occupation, the film examines a series of events and shows what might have happened if one thing had gone differently in each instance. The main protagonists are two friends, Antoine and Jean, both in love with Marie-Anne, and both actively involved with the Resistance.

Credits: Producer, Christine Gouze-Renal ; director, Edouard Molinaro ; writers, Edouard Molinaro, Paul Guimard, Pierre Kast ; photography, Alain Levent ; music, Jose Berghams.
Cast: Claude Rich, Pierre Clementi, Marie-Helene Breillat, Jacques Spiesser, Jean Desailly

results.title: L'invitee = the Guest
results.creator_credit: Vittorio De Seta and Jean-Roch Rognoni
results.brief_description:
When she discovers her husband has come home with a mistress, Anne leaves her home in Paris and spends the night in her office where she meets Francois, an architect. Without further ado, Francois invites her to a business trip to the South of France.

Credits: Producer, Jean-Roch Rognoni ; director, Vittorio De Seta; writers, Lucile Laks, Tonino Guerra, Frantz Andre Burguet, Vittorio De Seta, Monique Lange ; photography, Luciano Tovoli ; music, Georges Garvarentz.
Cast: Michel Piccoli, Joanna Shimkus, Jacques Perrin, Lorna Heilbron, Paul Barge, Clotilde Joanno, Jacques Rispal.

results.title: L'intrepide = the Intrepid
results.brief_description:
Didier, a surgeon in a Paris hospital, saves the life of Canello, a famous gangster. In order to show Didier how grateful he really is, Canello offers to eliminate Lydie, Didier’s overbearing fiancee. The contract on Lydie must be executed during an overnight train trip. But at the last minute, Lydie gives her seat to an other woman. Didier must now save the woman from becoming a victim of Canello.

Credits: Producer, Alain Darbon ; director, Jean Girault ; writer, Jacques Wilfried, Andre Versini, Rene Versini ; photography, Guy Suzuki ; music, Raymond Lefevre.
Cast: Louis Velle, Claudine Auger, Juliette Mills, Roger Hanin, Michel Galabru.

results.title: L'incoronazione di Poppea
results.creator_credit: Peter Hall, Robin Lough, Glyndebourne Productions and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: A dramatic opera of passion and betrayal, “L’Incoronazione di Poppea” by Claudio Monteverdi, libretto by Francesco Busenello, tells the amoral story of the Roman Emperor Nero’s love affair with the scheming and seductive Poppea. Maria Ewing plays the manipulative and evil Poppea and Dennis Bailey is Nerone, her Emperor lover, with a supporting cast including Cynthia Clarey, Robert Lloyd, Elizabeth Gale, Dale Duesing. Features the Glyndebourne Chorus and the London Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Raymond Leppard who is also responsible for making this modern edition of the opera. Includes an introduction by Peter Hall and a translated printed program in English and Italian. Sung in Italian. Recorded for television as part of the Glyndebourne Festival series.

results.title: L'immortelle = the Immortal Woman
results.creator_credit: Alain Robbe-Grillet and Dino De Laurentiis
results.brief_description:
Andre and Leilah meet and become lovers. After a bizarre car accident, Leilah dies. Andre sets out to investigate Leilah’s death. Awards: Prix Louis-Delluc 1963.

Credits: Producer: Dino De Laurentiis ; director, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; writer, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; photography, Maurice Barry ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Jacques Doniol-Valcroze, Francoise Brion.

results.title: L'île Mystérieruse
results.brief_description: French videomaker Cahen eloquently captures atmospherics to create a sound and colour scape of Easter Island, The Mysterious Island. He writes, ‘Traversed by light and colors, images of the empty landscape seem to be haunted by a gaze, a desire to see, to know.’ Children play in the shallows of a small boat harbour. Is this a clue to the mystery?

results.title: L'Ile de la Cite
results.creator_credit: John Seabourne and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: An American girl visits the Ile de la Cite, the quais de la Seine and Ile Saint-Louis and has tea with a French friend. Conversation with a quayside bookseller, explanations of the island’s monuments and buildings and a humorous incident involving a phone call are also included. In French langauge.

results.title: L'idiot = the Idiot
results.brief_description:
Russian prince Muichkine returns to St. Petersburg after a stay in a Swiss mental hospital. Blissfully unaware of the greater social problems of his country, the prince believes that love and goodness reign supreme around him. He becomes betrothed to an innocent young girl while trying to save a less-innocent woman from her downfall. Jealousy and his own naivete conjoin to bring about an unimaginable tragedy. ‘L’idiot’ was remade in Japan by Akira Kurosawa (1951) and in Russia by Ivan Pyriev (1958).

Credits: Producer, Sacha Gordine ; director, Georges Lampin ; writers, Charles Spaak, Georges Raewsky ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Maurice Thiriet, V. de Butzow.
Cast: Gerard Philipe, Edwige Feuillere, Lucien Coedel, Nathalie Nattier, Marguerite Moreno, Jean Debucourt, Sylvie.
